content: The Act is named the "Building Our Largest Dementia Infrastructure for Alzheimer's Act" or the "BOLD Infrastructure for Alzheimer's Act." It aims to promote public health knowledge and awareness of Alzheimer's disease, cognitive decline, and brain health under the Alzheimer's Disease and Healthy Aging Program. Amendments are made to the Public Health Service Act to include programs for dementia. The "Building Our Largest Dementia Infrastructure for Alzheimer's Act" or the "BOLD Infrastructure for Alzheimer's Act" promotes public health knowledge and awareness of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. Grants will be awarded to establish regional centers to address Alzheimer's disease by advancing public health officials' awareness. The "BOLD Infrastructure for Alzheimer's Act" aims to raise awareness about Alzheimer's disease and related dementias among public health officials, healthcare professionals, and the general public. It focuses on translating research findings into evidence-based interventions for affected populations and caregivers, as well as expanding activities through public-private partnerships. The eligibility requirements for receiving a grant under the "BOLD Infrastructure for Alzheimer's Act" include coordinating with existing programs, promoting evidence-based interventions for individuals with Alzheimer's disease, and prioritizing activities to expand efforts in implementing interventions. The "BOLD Infrastructure for Alzheimer's Act" aims to implement evidence-based practices for Alzheimer's disease and related dementias, including training health professionals, supporting early detection, reducing hospitalizations, cognitive decline, and providing caregiver support. The "BOLD Infrastructure for Alzheimer's Act" focuses on implementing evidence-based practices for Alzheimer's disease and related dementias, including reducing health disparities, supporting care planning, and other relevant activities identified by the Secretary or the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Considerations for awarding grants include providing services to rural areas or underserved populations and building on existing infrastructure. The "BOLD Infrastructure for Alzheimer's Act" aims to award grants to organizations with experience in providing care or conducting research related to Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. The Secretary will ensure equitable distribution of awards based on geographic area and disease burden within sub-populations. Data reporting and program oversight are required for all grants awarded under this subsection. The "BOLD Infrastructure for Alzheimer's Act" requires entities receiving grants to submit data on funded programs and outcomes. The Secretary will improve data analysis on Alzheimer's disease and related dementias, including cognitive decline and health disparities. The Secretary may award grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements to eligible public or nonprofit entities for activities related to cognitive decline. Eligible entities include institutions of higher education, health departments, and Indian tribes. Data sources for analysis may include the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System and the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey. The Secretary shall coordinate activities related to dementia to avoid duplication with other agencies. Section 398 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to provide cooperative agreements to states for Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. The Secretary will award cooperative agreements to health departments to address Alzheimer's disease and related dementias, focusing on reducing cognitive decline, supporting caregivers, and implementing evidence-based interventions such as public education, early detection, and reducing hospitalizations. The Secretary will award cooperative agreements to health departments to address Alzheimer's disease and related dementias, focusing on reducing cognitive decline, supporting caregivers, and implementing evidence-based interventions such as public education, early detection, and reducing hospitalizations. Preference will be given to applications that focus on specific activities identified by the Secretary or the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. To be eligible for a cooperative agreement under this section, an entity must submit an application detailing plans to educate individuals on Alzheimer's disease, workforce development, and program evaluation. Preference is given to applications addressing health disparities in populations with high prevalence of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. The applicant must detail how they will support activities identified by the CDC, coordinate with federal, tribal, and state programs, and evaluate program effectiveness. Health departments awarded a cooperative agreement must provide 30% matching funds from non-federal sources. The Secretary has the authority to waive the matching requirement for health departments, states, tribes, and tribal organizations if it would cause hardship in carrying out the cooperative agreement. The Secretary must ensure no duplication of effort in activities under the cooperative agreement. Activities under cooperative agreements awarded under this subpart should not duplicate efforts of other agencies within the Department of Health and Human Services related to activities for Alzheimer's disease and related dementias.
